Lars Clausen wrote:
> Hi!
> 
> I'm going to do further work on the DominnameQueueAssignmentPolicy that
> Bjarne posted earlier, which splits the host name down to the last two
> parts (need to handle IP addresses correctly).  As part of that, I'm
> doing a unit test, which is showing me that the result of
> HostnameQueueAssignmentPolicy.getClassKey isn't exactly the domain name,
> but can also include port number at least.  Is there some fixed
> definition of the queue key format, or should I just assume that
> whatever the source says is definition enough (I generally don't like
> doing the latter, since source-based definitions are rarely stable)?

Queue names can be arbitrary Strings -- the exact format depends on the
QueueAssignmentPolicy in use. Other parts of the code are not looking
into the Strings for meaningful info -- as far as the code is concerned,
they're arbitrary opaque keys. So, the most important consumer of the key
'format' is probably the human operator who will occasionally view these
queue names in Frontier reports.

Historically (pre-BDB), we ensured that queue names were valid filenames,
since each queue was represented by several files with names derived from
the queue name. Using BdbFrontier, this isn't imperative, and if a future
new Frontier again wants to use queue names to help generate file names,
it could handle the necessary escaping itself.

- Gordon @ IA
